input:
2. A 72-year-old female with a history of giant cell arteritis treated intermittently with steroids presents with sudden vision loss in her left eye that started two days ago. She describes the loss as a dark spot in the center of her vision, now encompassing most of the visual field in that eye, accompanied by mild eye discomfort. She also reports jaw claudication and scalp tenderness over the past week. On examination, her visual acuity in the left eye is reduced to counting fingers, and there is a pronounced relative afferent pupillary defect. Fundoscopy reveals a pale, swollen optic disc with surrounding hemorrhages. Laboratory workup shows markedly elevated ESR and CRP, suggestive of active inflammation. The right eye demonstrates normal vision and an unremarkable fundoscopic appearance. The presentation and labs support a diagnosis of arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy secondary to giant cell arteritis.
What brings you in today?
output:
THINKING: The patient is probably scared because her vision is getting worse, and she might not understand exactly what’s happening. She might just describe her symptoms vaguely, trying to explain her sudden loss of vision and discomfort. She could be feeling confused or worried about what the doctor might find.

ANSWER: I… I just started seeing this really dark spot in my left eye, and it’s like my whole sight there is gone now. It happened pretty quick, and I feel a bit of discomfort in that eye too. I’ve been feeling kind of tired and achey lately, and my head’s been tender, but I didn’t think it was anything serious.

input: 2. A 72-year-old female with a history of giant cell arteritis treated intermittently with steroids presents with sudden vision loss in her left eye that started two days ago. She describes the loss as a dark spot in the center of her vision, now encompassing most of the visual field in that eye, accompanied by mild eye discomfort. She also reports jaw claudication and scalp tenderness over the past week. On examination, her visual acuity in the left eye is reduced to counting fingers, and there is a pronounced relative afferent pupillary defect. Fundoscopy reveals a pale, swollen optic disc with surrounding hemorrhages. Laboratory workup shows markedly elevated ESR and CRP, suggestive of active inflammation. The right eye demonstrates normal vision and an unremarkable fundoscopic appearance. The presentation and labs support a diagnosis of arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy secondary to giant cell arteritis.Can you tell me more about how these symptoms started, how they have changed over time, and if you've noticed anything else unusual, like any other aches, headaches, or changes in your health?
output: Well, it kinda just happened all of a sudden, like I looked and it was all dark in that eye, and it’s been like that for a couple of days now. It seems to have gotten worse, 'cause now I can't see much at all. I’ve had some pain in my head and my jaw hurts when I chew, and my scalp’s been tender too, but I thought maybe it was just normal for me. I haven't noticed anything else really, but I do feel a bit shaky or tired sometimes.

input: 2. A 72-year-old female with a history of giant cell arteritis treated intermittently with steroids presents with sudden vision loss in her left eye that started two days ago. She describes the loss as a dark spot in the center of her vision, now encompassing most of the visual field in that eye, accompanied by mild eye discomfort. She also reports jaw claudication and scalp tenderness over the past week. On examination, her visual acuity in the left eye is reduced to counting fingers, and there is a pronounced relative afferent pupillary defect. Fundoscopy reveals a pale, swollen optic disc with surrounding hemorrhages. Laboratory workup shows markedly elevated ESR and CRP, suggestive of active inflammation. The right eye demonstrates normal vision and an unremarkable fundoscopic appearance. The presentation and labs support a diagnosis of arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy secondary to giant cell arteritis.Can you tell me if you’ve noticed any scalp tenderness or scalp pain when touching or combing your hair, and whether you’ve experienced any new headaches, especially around your temples?
output: Um, yeah, my scalp’s been kind of tender, especially when I touch or run my fingers through my hair, and I did notice a new headache. It’s like a dull ache around my temples, mostly on the side that's hurting my eye.

input: 2. A 72-year-old female with a history of giant cell arteritis treated intermittently with steroids presents with sudden vision loss in her left eye that started two days ago. She describes the loss as a dark spot in the center of her vision, now encompassing most of the visual field in that eye, accompanied by mild eye discomfort. She also reports jaw claudication and scalp tenderness over the past week. On examination, her visual acuity in the left eye is reduced to counting fingers, and there is a pronounced relative afferent pupillary defect. Fundoscopy reveals a pale, swollen optic disc with surrounding hemorrhages. Laboratory workup shows markedly elevated ESR and CRP, suggestive of active inflammation. The right eye demonstrates normal vision and an unremarkable fundoscopic appearance. The presentation and labs support a diagnosis of arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy secondary to giant cell arteritis.Can you tell me if you've noticed any other symptoms like fever, weight loss, muscle aches, or any changes in your overall energy levels? Also, have you experienced any recent scalp pain or tenderness beyond the scalp tenderness you've mentioned, or difficulty opening your mouth?
output: Well, I do feel kind of tired more often, and I’ve noticed I’m a bit achey sometimes, but I wasn’t sure if it was just me being old or sleepy. The scalp pain has been there for a little while – it’s just more sensitive when I touch it, and I tried to open my mouth wider the other day, but it hurt. That’s about it, really.

The right eye demonstrates normal vision and an unremarkable fundoscopic appearance. The presentation and labs support a diagnosis of arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy secondary to giant cell arteritis.Does the patient have any jaw pain or tenderness when chewing, which could suggest jaw claudication?
output: I do sometimes get a little bit of pain when I chew, but it's not really sharp or anything—it just feels kind of tired or achy.

input: 2. A 72-year-old female with a history of giant cell arteritis treated intermittently with steroids presents with sudden vision loss in her left eye that started two days ago. She also reports jaw claudication and scalp tenderness over the past week. The right eye demonstrates normal vision and an unremarkable fundoscopic appearance. The presentation and labs support a diagnosis of arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy secondary to giant cell arteritis.Have you experienced any recent fevers, chills, night sweats, or unexplained weight loss? Also, do you have any history of cardiovascular disease, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, or previous blood clots?
output: Um, I guess I’ve felt a little hot and shaky sometimes, but I didn’t think much of it. I haven’t lost any weight that I know of, and I don’t really remember having fevers or night sweats. As for other health stuff, I do have high blood pressure sometimes, and I’ve had some rough times with my heart, I suppose, but I don’t know about blood clots or anything like that.

output: Um, I think I’ve been feeling a bit more tired than usual, and maybe a little chilly sometimes, but I thought that was just because it’s been cold lately. I haven’t really had a fever or anything like that.

The right eye demonstrates normal vision and an unremarkable fundoscopic appearance. The presentation and labs support a diagnosis of arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy secondary to giant cell arteritis.Have you experienced any additional visual problems since the onset, such as seeing flashes, new floaters, or a visual field defect in the affected eye?
output: No, I haven't noticed any flashes or floaters, but my vision just keeps getting worse, like this dark thing taking over. I haven't seen anything new, at least I think.

input: 2. A 72-year-old female with a history of giant cell arteritis treated intermittently with steroids presents with sudden vision loss in her left eye that started two days ago. She also reports jaw claudication and scalp tenderness over the past week. On examination, her visual acuity in the left eye is reduced to counting fingers, and there is a pronounced relative afferent pupillary defect. Fundoscopy reveals a pale, swollen optic disc with surrounding hemorrhages. Laboratory workup shows markedly elevated ESR and CRP, suggestive of active inflammation. The right eye demonstrates normal vision and an unremarkable fundoscopic appearance. The presentation and labs support a diagnosis of arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy secondary to giant cell arteritis.Have you noticed any other symptoms such as scalp pain when brushing your hair, or new weakness or numbness in your limbs that might suggest more widespread vascular involvement?
output: Um, I think I’ve been having this scalp tenderness on and off, especially when I brush my hair, but I thought it was just normal. I haven’t noticed anything else like weakness or numbness, but I do feel a bit more tired than usual.
